1.text: Whither is thy beloved gone, Thou fairest among women? Whither is thy beloved turned aside? And we will seek him with thee.

2.text: My beloved is gone down into his garden, to the beds of spices, To feed in the gardens and to gather lilies.

3.text: I am my beloved’s, and my beloved is mine: He feedeth [his flock] among the lilies.

4.text: Thou art fair, my love, as Tirzah, Comely as Jerusalem, Terrible as troops with banners:

5.text: Turn away thine eyes from me, For they overcome me. Thy hair is as a flock of goats On the slopes of Gilead.

6.text: Thy teeth are like a flock of sheep Which go up from the washing; Which have all borne twins, And none is barren among them.

7.text: As a piece of a pomegranate are thy temples Behind thy veil.

8.text: There are threescore queens, and fourscore concubines, And virgins without number:

9.text: My dove, mine undefiled, is but one; She is the only one of her mother, She is the choice one of her that bore her. The daughters saw her, and they called her blessed; The queens and the concubines, and they praised her.

10.text: Who is she that looketh forth as the dawn, Fair as the moon, clear as the sun, Terrible as troops with banners?

11.text: I went down into the garden of nuts, To see the verdure of the valley, To see whether the vine budded, Whether the pomegranates blossomed.

12.text: Before I was aware, My soul set me upon the chariots of my willing people.

13.text: Return, return, O Shulamite; Return, return, that we may look upon thee.—What would ye look upon in the Shulamite?—As it were the dance of two camps.
